pathway: Pharmacy First - Infected Insect Bites (≥1 year)

metadata.niceGuideline: NICE CKS Insect Bites and Stings

notes: Exclude pregnant individuals under 16 years and patients without signs of infection—rapid-onset reactions are usually inflammatory/allergic and resolve with self-care.

Document bite/sting history (location, timing, travel history, animal/human exposure), lesion photography if available, systemic symptoms, comorbidities and allergy status before deciding on PGD supply.
Share safety-netting: demarcate erythema, advise urgent review if spreading rapidly, fever, lymphangitis, severe pain, or systemic features occur.
Recommend oral antihistamines, topical corticosteroids and avoidance of scratching to reduce inflammation even when antibiotics are supplied.
Provide wound hygiene advice (wash with soap/water, keep nails short, avoid occlusive dressings) and counsel that mild redness/itching can persist up to 10 days.

decisionTree.title: Consider the risk of deterioration or serious illness
decisionTree.question: Does the patient meet urgent referral criteria?

urgentCriteria: Systemically very unwell or NEWS2 trigger (tachycardia, fever, hypotension).
Rapidly spreading cellulitis, lymphangitis or suspicion of sepsis/necrotising infection.
Facial/periorbital involvement, airway compromise, or bites on genitals.
redFlags: Suspected insect-borne disease (malaria, Lyme disease) requiring medical assessment.
Immunocompromised host (chemotherapy, uncontrolled diabetes, chronic ulcer).

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Consider NEWS2 before arranging emergency care.
Refer to GP, urgent care or A&E/999 as clinically indicated.
Do not supply under PGD; provide written safety-netting.

no.title: Exposure needing medical review
no.question: Does the patient meet ANY of the following criteria?

highRiskExposures: Bite or scratch caused by animal(s).
Tick bite in the UK plus erythema migrans or Lyme disease signs.
Bite/sting acquired outside the UK with concern for malaria or other vector-borne disease.
Bite/sting caused by unusual or exotic insect.

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Refer to GP or appropriate service for further assessment and prophylaxis.
Document exposure details and provide safety-netting advice.

no.title: Timing since bite
no.question: Has it been at least 48 hours since the initial bite or sting?

timingNotes: Most inflammatory reactions improve within 48 hours without antibiotics.
Delay antibiotic consideration until ≥48 hours unless patient becomes systemically unwell.

no.title: Too early for infection
actions: Recommend self-care, oral antihistamines and/or topical steroids.
Advise patient to return if symptoms worsen or persist beyond 48 hours.

yes.title: Symptom assessment
yes.question: Is itch the principal symptom (no other infection signs)?

itchAdvice: Normal redness/itching can last up to 10 days.
Encourage avoidance of scratching and continue non-prescription treatments.

yes.title: Likely inflammatory reaction
actions: Recommend self-care, oral antihistamine and/or topical steroids.
Provide safety-netting and explain infection is unlikely.

no.title: Acute infection symptoms
no.question: Does the patient have acute onset of ≥3 infection symptoms?

infectionSymptoms: Pain or tenderness at the bite site.
Skin around the bite feels hot to touch.

no.title: Monitor and support
actions: Recommend self-care and OTC antihistamine/topical steroid.
Reassure that itching can persist up to 10 days and infection remains unlikely.
Avoid scratching to reduce inflammation and infection risk.

yes.title: Signs of spreading infection
yes.question: Does the patient meet ANY of the following criteria?

spreadingSigns: Redness/swelling surrounding the bite is spreading.
Evidence of pustular discharge at the bite/sting site.

no.title: Localised infection suspected
actions: Demarcate erythema and ask patient to monitor.
Provide self-care advice and review if symptoms worsen or fail to improve after 3 days of OTC treatment.

yes.title: Gateway point
yes.question: Does the patient meet ANY escalation criteria (requires referral)?

escalationCriteria: Comorbidity that may delay resolution (peripheral arterial disease, chronic venous insufficiency, lymphoedema, morbid obesity).
Severe pain out of proportion to the wound (consider toxin-producing bacteria).
Significant fluid/pus collection at site (consider incision and drainage).

yes.title: Referral required
actions: Refer to GP/urgent care for potential oral/IV therapy or procedural management.
Continue supportive care and document reasons for referral.

no.title: Reported penicillin allergy
no.question: Is there a confirmed penicillin allergy?

yes.title: Erythromycin (penicillin allergy + pregnancy)

dose.Adults: 500 mg four times daily (or 1 g twice daily modified-release) for 5 days.

formulations: Oral suspension 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL
plus: Counsel regarding GI effects and importance of completing 5-day course.
Advise to seek review if jaundice, severe vomiting or rash occurs.
yes.followUp: Return/phone GP if no improvement within 2–3 days or earlier if worsening.

no.title: Clarithromycin (penicillin allergy)
plus: Check drug interactions (statins, anticoagulants, QT prolongation).
Encourage hydration and adherence; report taste changes or GI upset if severe.
no.followUp: Reassess if symptoms worsen or fail to improve after 2–3 days.

no.title: Flucloxacillin (first line)
formulations: Oral solution 125 mg/5 mL or 250 mg/5 mL (standard and sugar-free)
no.route: Oral on an empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after food).
plus: Warn that sugar-free solutions may taste unpleasant; discuss alternatives if adherence at risk.
Advise monitoring for GI upset or cholestatic jaundice; stop and seek advice if symptoms occur.
no.followUp: Return if symptoms worsen or do not improve after completion of 5 days.
